213267928883911.description:
This group is a FREE community group open to moms and dads looking to receive or give positive information about birth and an opportunity to connect with and gain support from other like-minded parents. 

We meet on the fourth Wednesday of the month at 7pm at Marketplace Family Chiropractic Centre, 80 Marketplace Avenue, Unit J2 Barrhaven. 

Future meeting dates:  March 26th, April 30th (5th Wednesday), May 28th, June 25th, July 23rd, August 27th, September 24th, October 22nd, November 26th.

To be notified of upcoming meetings you can enter your address on this page:  http://yourbirthcoach.com/join-the-community/positive-birth-movement/

"Women have been successfully birthing babies since the beginning of time and I believe YOU can do it to. I have had three incredibly wonderful natural home birth experiences in 2006, 2009, and 2011. I have supported many women through pregnancy and birth. I have seen how information, support, and belief in yourself, your baby, and birth can transform women, families, and lives forever."

“For me an empowered birth is one where I am the one who makes the decisions for me and my baby. Where I am in an environment of love, support, and respect for the power within my body to successfully birth my baby. Where I can be free to express anything I need to express; sound, movement, fear, love, ecstasy in a place that my expression will not lead to interference from the outside. I believe women have the ability to create an empowering birth experience regardless of if the birth outcome is natural, medicated, or surgical. When women are making the decisions for their bodies and their babies out of education, faith, belief and confidence in themselves and not out of fear or manipulation they will be empowered. I believe in the human body, in it’s power, and in birth’s ability to transform a person, woman, wife, and mother.” 

For more info see: 
http://yourbirthcoach.com
http://naturalbirthbabyandbeyond.com
http://facebook.com/yourbirthcoachdrnancy


or contact Nancy via:
info@yourbirthcoach.com
613-823-1255

Topics previously discussed:
'Positive Birth Is...'
'Prenatal Testing'
'Oxytocin'
'Improving Birth'
 'Risk'
 'Fear'
 'The Hour After Birth'
 'Choices in Birth'
 'Birth Place'
 'Language of Birth'
'Images of Birth'
213267928883911.name: Positive Birth Ottawa

215500168632822.description:
YES - CANADIAN TOUR - MARCH 2014
Victoria, Vancouver, Kelowna, Calgary, Edmonton, Winnipeg, Oshawa, Ottawa, Quebec City & Hamilton.

Exclusive Presale for YES Fans at yesworld.com : All Tickets, plus extra Meet & Greet Packages and VIP Packages all go on sale only at http://yesworld.com on Thursday 12th December at 10am (local venue time). 

Public ticket sale won't begin until Monday 16th December.

THREE ALBUM TOUR
In March 2014, the iconic and Grammy-winning rock band YES will bring their concert tour to Canada, unveiling a true classic rock triple-header by performing three of their most popular albums in their entirety, all in one concert: 1971’s THE YES ALBUM, 1972’s CLOSE TO THE EDGE, and 1977’s GOING FOR THE ONE.

Music audiences across Canada will experience the albums – each representing an important milestone in YES’ career which encompasses sales of close to 50 million albums worldwide – performed from beginning to end.

REVIEW
Chris Epting of AOL’s Noisecreep.com said: “Yes demonstrates why they remain one of the most vaunted and respected musical forces in progressive rock among both fans and players alike… Singer Jon Davison, now a year into his role as frontman demonstrated from the outset that he is more than up to the task… At one time it was about exploration, experimentation and an elegant, seamless blending of many musical styles into one space-age storm that remains inspired, atmospheric and very hard to categorize. This was a feast for the followers; faithful renditions for the many die hard starship troopers that were no doubt reliving many scrapbook Yes memories over the years. But the show was not about mere nostalgia. This is a band that still feels strangely new, simply by doing what they do, pushing the boundaries and presenting songs that, like the wildly colorful and original Roger Dean artwork that represents them, are just beautifully designed and built to last.”

SPECIAL PACKAGES
YES is proud to provide special show packages, which include near-stage seating, a Meet and Greet with the band, exclusive limited-edition gifts from YES, and much more.

Yes - Meet & Greet Package
Package includes:
One reserved ticket located in the first 5 rows of the stage
Exclusive autograph session with Yes
Personal photograph with Yes
Specially designed tour shirt (limited to VIP packages only)
Collectible tour poster (numbered, limited)
Remastered, super audio CD copy of "Close to the Edge"
Set of official Yes guitar picks (with case)
Official meet & greet laminate
On-site VIP host
Limited availability

Yes - VIP Tour Package
Package includes:
One reserved ticket located in the first 15 rows of the stage
Specially designed tour shirt (limited to VIP packages only)
Collectible tour poster (numbered, limited)
Remastered, super audio CD copy of "Close to the Edge"
Set of official Yes guitar picks (with case)
Commemorative VIP laminate
Limited availability

TIMES
All Shows are Three Album Shows with Doors at 6:30pm, Show at 7:30pm. Curfew at 11:00pm.

MORE INFO
More info at http://yesworld.com/2013/12/yes-announce-triple-album-tour-in-canada-for-march-2014/
215500168632822.name: YES live at Southam Hall @ National Arts Centre , Ottawa, ON

215535515307221.description:
Editor and documentary filmmaker Robert McTavish showcases The Line has Shattered at the fourth annual VERSeFest in Ottawa with a film screening and panel discussion.

Saturday, March 29, 2014
1:30pm: "The Line has Shattered" — Film Screening & Panel
Mercury Lounge, 55 Byward Market Square
Fifty years ago, American poets Charles Olson, Allen Ginsberg, Robert Creeley, Robert Duncan, and Denise Levertov came to Vancouver for a poetry conference that was radical for its time and remains inspiring to this day. The Line has Shattered examines how a rising generation was inspired to embrace new, open forms of poetry, and the field of poetry itself as a meaningful experience for a lifetime's work.

Following the film, there will be a panel discussion lead by Robert McTavish, with guests Roy MacSkimming, Robert Hogg and William Hawkins.

Robert McTavish’s documentary films include What to make of it all? The life and poetry of John Newlove and The Line has Shattered: Vancouver’s Landmark 1963 Poetry Conference. He is the editor of A Long Continual Argument: The Selected Poems of John Newlove (Chaudière Books, Ottawa, 2007) and his radio work includes the documentary Phyllis Webb: The Art of Ideas for CBC Radio’s IDEAS.

Check the VERSeFest website for other events.
http://www.versefest.ca/2014/

http://www.chaudierebooks.blogspot.ca/2014/03/robert-mctavish-screens-line-has.html
215535515307221.name: Robert McTavish screens "The Line has Shattered" at Ottawa's VERSeFest

217298735147729.description:
EARS AND EYES W/ 180 PROJECTS PRESENTS:

A night of ghostly folk and alternative space music from kindhearted people as far as Saskatoon and as close as Sault Ste. Marie. This show is brought to you by Jackson Reed & Jessica Bolduc (Ears and Eyes - Sault Music and Art Community) and Andrea Pinheiro (180 Projects). We hope you can come. 

---------------------------------------------------------------

About Twin Voices:

Twin Voices is an indie electro-folk project with roots in the Ottawa Valley and wings in Saskatoon and Montreal. Laura Beach crafts a dark and lovely sound with live looping of violin, voice, percussion and guitar. Her performance is equal parts stunning simplicity and playful complexity.

Listen: https://twinvoices.bandcamp.com/

About Gunner and Smith:

It’s been an eventful past four years for Saskatoon’s Gunner & Smith. Starting in 2010 as a solo project by folk artist Geoff Smith, the band evolved into a multi-member indie country rock ensemble that traverses the rocky line between post-prairies balladeering and grit-covered rockers for those given to heavy highway drives and long, expansive thoughts. Gunner & Smith recently released their first full-length album, He Once Was a Good Man, on Feb. 25th, 2014.

Listen: http://gunnerandsmith.bandcamp.com/

About Heritage: 

Heritage is the low-fi field recording/experimental folk project by Sault Ste. Marie native Jackson Reed. With influences steeped in alternative-country and independent Canadiana music, Jackson brings an honest, stripped down and naked approach to the traditional singer songwriter profile.

Listen: http://heritageheritage.bandcamp.com

---------------------------------------------------------------

THE HAIRY DETAILS: 

$5 students, $10 general
Doors 7:30, show at 8:00
All Ages
180 Projects - 180 Gore Street
Thursday May 29th, 2014

Praise and Worship, at St. Philip's Parish in Richmond. We will begin setting up and choosing songs right after the Stations of the Cross, which end at about 7:30. All are welcome to come for the Stations as well!

A bit of background about these events. Essentially a small group of us have been getting together since November to meet up a few times a month and just praise God, wherever we could meet up. We wanted to find an authentic heart of worship. To lay aside egos, big set ups, distractions- anything not of God- and find the joy of praise in simplicity. As interest grew, we needed bigger spaces (Thanks St. Philip's!).

221875711341946.description:
We are happy to announce that our May artist will be Rebekah Elkerton! 

Rebekah Elkerton is a 24 year old artist from Chippewas of the Thames First Nation. Rebekah graduated from Carleton University with a Bachelor of Arts in Women’s and Gender Studies and will begin her Graduate studies in the Fall of 2014. She grew up in the Toronto area and at a very young age used her passion for drawing and painting as an outlet to express herself. 

In her teen years Rebekah attended a regional arts secondary school program before moving to Ottawa in 2007 to begin her post-secondary studies. Throughout her studies and personal experiences, Rebekah discovered her passion of improving the lives of Indigenous women. Through a creative interplay of striking colors, Rebekah paints portraits of women with the aim of decolonizing stereotypical images of women. 

Some of her portraits are self-portraits while others are representations of close friends who have shared their stories of pain and struggle with her. Each painting is completed with the use of Acrylic paint on salvaged wood, as a means of reviving an otherwise discarded material.

Vernissage will include snacks, spoken word and music!

Performers: 

Vera Wabegijig 
Poet, Writer and Media Artist. 
w: http://verawaabegeeshig.wordpress.com/

Giselle Gotti-Chanel
Drag Performer
f: https://www.facebook.com/giselle.gotti?fref=ts

***Tune in, Aboriginal CKCU Radio 93.1fm Program (http://aboriginalckcu.com/) on April 27th from 9am - 10am. Rebekah Elkerton will be interviewed by Artist - Jaime Koebel, along side our June artist Mark Seabrook. Both Mark and Rebekah will discuss how they started out, their inspirations and the theme of their show!***

More details about Marks show: 
Facebook: Sketches - Art by Mark Seabrook
221875711341946.name: Anishinaabe Woman - Art by Rebekah Elkerton

221901341352028.description:
Which of us has not been caught short by our need for a toilet? The Crohns and Colitis Foundation surveyed their members in 2008 only to find that more than 75% of them had been humiliated in this way. What parent has not had their child urinate or defecate behind a tree in a park? Which pregnant woman, tourist, bus user, cyclist or jogger has not had moments where they worry about getting to a facility in time?

Although Ottawa does have public restrooms in large parks, their hours do not accommodate need. Small parks, rinks and splash pads often have no washroom facilities at all. transit stations do not have public toilets. In the downtown, where bars and restaurants are located, residents complain about people urinating after hours in laneways and buildings, and restaurant and bar owners fret about non-paying customers using their washrooms. Accessible toilets are a public health issue. The current situation is unacceptable in a capital city!

Please join Joan Kuyek, Chair of the “GottaGo!” campaign for a discussion of this initiative aimed to create a network of safe, accessible, free, clean and environmentally responsible public toilets and water fountains in key public places in Ottawa, learn what actions other municipalities are taking to match the effective public toilet programs of Tokyo, Paris, London, Seoul, Portland (Oregon) and other progressive cities. 

Noon 
Wednesday April 16 2014 
Octopus Books Centretown Location 
@ 25One Community (2nd Floor, 251 Bank St.)

Free

Bring Your Lunch!

“Public toilets represent society’s finest aspirations about responsible civil behaviour. A great city has great public toilets”  (Bridgeman). 

ABOUT THE SPEAKER
Joan Kuyek is the chair of GottaGo!  and has been an activist organizer since the 1960s, based in Kingston  and then in Sudbury. In 1999, she moved to Ottawa as the founding National Co-ordinator of MiningWatch Canada. Retired  in 2009,  she continues to work as a contract instructor at Carleton, Queen’s and Algoma Universities, and with communities facing mining issues. She is the author of Community Organizing: A Holistic Approach (2011) and a number of other books and articles.
221901341352028.name: Lunchtime Roundtable: GottaGo! Ottawa Public Toilet Campaig

224752764390011.description:
This event is the public Installation of Ottawa  (Genoa) chapter's officers for the 2014 term.  This is a public ceremony for the community to come together to recognize the hard work of the young men of their community. The hardworking gentlemen will appreciate your attendance and support as they continue to work to become better men as well as do their community proud. A short ceremony will take place and then a light dinner and refreshments will be served after. Dress for this event is semi formal for guests.

For those who are unfamiliar with the Order of DeMolay. 

DeMolay is an organization dedicated to preparing young men to lead successful, happy, and productive lives. Basing its approach on timeless principles and practical, hands-on experience, DeMolay opens doors for young men aged 12 to 21 by developing the civic awareness, personal responsibility and leadership skills so vitally needed in society today. DeMolay combines this serious mission with a fun approach that builds important bonds of Brotherhood among members in more than 1,000 chapters worldwide.
DeMolay alumni include Walt Disney, John Wayne, Walter Cronkite, football Hall-of-Famer Fran Tarkenton, legendary Nebraska football coach Tom Osborne, news anchor David Goodnow and many others. Each has spoken eloquently of the life-changing benefit gained from their involvement in DeMolay.
224752764390011.name: Ottawa Chapter Installation of Officers 2014

224848551038818.description:
L’IMPORTANCE D’AMIS ET DE LA FAMILLE
Pour les gens qui relèvent des défis d’endurance, plusieurs aspects sont pris en considérations comme l'entrainement, l’alimentation, l’équipement, le sommeil,  les breuvages, suppléments alimentaires et autres…

Mais étant donné que ces défis sont souvent sur de longues distances, on ne parle pas beaucoup de l’effet de l’encouragement d’amis et de nos familles tout au long des parcours.

A mon premier ½ Marathon (Ottawa 2013), mon papa a eu la brillante idée de se rendre à différents points du parcours en vélo afin de m’encourager tout au long du défi. Leurs présences et encouragements m’ont été d’une grande source de motivation et d’énergie incroyable. Ce fut aussi plus plaisant pour eux car ils n’ont pas passé 1h44 à m’attendre a l’arrivée :) Et grâce a eux, j’ai des souvenirs de l’événement  qui ne sont normalement pas capturés https://www.facebook.com/remi.bachand/media_set?set=a.10152849183965006.1073741827.857865005&type=3

PLUS GROS DEFI A DATE
Cette année, je me suis inscris a mon plus grand défi a date. C’est le 40e marathon d’Ottawa, c’est plus de 40km et c’est a l’aube de mes 40 ans (jvous es tu dis?…). En partant, je suis chanceux car nous sommes plusieurs a faire le marathon incluant Magalie qui va rester avec moi durant toute la distance. HEIN MAG!!!??

NOUS AVONS BESOINS DE VOUS!
Alors pour ma fête et pour ce défi, je vous invite à venir nous encourager tout au long du trajet et ensuite de venir diner avec nous (resto a déterminer).

POINT DE RENCONTRE AU DÉPART ET A L’ARRIVÉE
La tradition continue avec le point de rencontre au parc de la confédération (Statue avec un aigle)

https://www.google.com/maps/place/Elgin+Cafe/@45.421547,-75.693442,3a,75y,73.5h,90t/data=!3m4!1e1!3m2!1sr9Dre1vFY0h_h_jcE8GvZA!2e0!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x7dbc0b2ddf4ba35d!6m1!1e1

en face de l’hôtel Lord Elgin. Une fois la ligne d’arrivée franchise, nous allons de peine et misère, se rendre a ce même point :)

COMMENT NOUS SUIVRE
Nous allons établir des estimations de nos temps pour les distances suivantes

10e km (Wellington et Clarendon)
20e km (Laurier et Eddy)
35e (St-Patrick et Vanier)
42e (ligne d’arrivée)

Ces estimés vous permettront de calculer vos déplacements :) Si certains d’entres vous ne peuvent être au départ a 7:00 AM, vous pouvez vous levez un peu plus tard et vous rendre en avance a ces points. Nous allons essayer de toujours rester du coté droite de la route (chiffres pair)
De plus, je vais utiliser le système de repérage en direct qui vous permettra de nous suivre end direct. 
http://www.racemyrace.com/hosted/ottawa_full.php

Vous allez devoir choisir la course (Events & Races) et ensuite clicker sur Live Tracking et Add Racer et de la vous pouvez m’ajouter par plusieurs critères
224848551038818.name: A  40 ans, au 40e d'Ottawa, 40+ km

225294861004922.description:
JOIN US FOR READINGS + A BOOK LAUNCH WITH CATHERINE OWEN & JILL BATTSON!

8pm
Tuesday, May 6, 2014

Ottawa Art Gallery
Arts Court
2 Daly Ave.
Ottawa, Ont.

Free
A hat will be passed.

On May 6, 2014, CATHERINE OWEN gives Designated Mourner (ECW Press, 2014) its Ottawa launch. She is the author of eight other collections of poetry, among them Trobairitz (Anvil Press 2012), Seeing Lessons (Wolsak & Wynn 2010) and Frenzy (Anvil Press 2009). Her poems are included in several recent anthologies such as Forcefield: 77 Women Poets of BC (Mothertongue Press, 2013). Her collection of memoirs and essays is called Catalysts: confrontations with the muse (W & W, 2012).

Frenzy won the Alberta Book Prize and other collections have been nominated for the BC Book Prize, the Re-lit, the CBC Prize, & the George Ryga Award. In 2011-2013, she wrote five songs for the eco-musical Awakening the Green Man, collaborated with multi-media artist Sydney Lancaster on Nest, served as an art model and writer for photographer Paul Saturley’s Pandemonium project, created a poemsong duo, The Lyrical Outlaws, and started a blog at blackcrow2.wordpress.com called The Relentless Adventures of OCD Crow. Owen edits, tutors, works on the TV show, Arrow, plays bass in Medea, co-runs Above & Beyond chapbook productions, and lives by the Fraser River. Her book of elegies, Designated Mourner has just been published and a chapbook called Rivulets is out from Alfred Gustav Press. Her web home is www.catherineowen.org. 

JILL BATTSON is an internationally published poet and poetry activist who is Poet Laureate Emeritus of Cobourg, Ontario. She was responsible for creating and running the successful poetry reading series The Poets’ Refuge and has initiated and produced many poetry events including The Poetry Express – a BYOV at Toronto’s Fringe Festival; Liminal Sisters – a language poetry event; The Festival of the Spoken Word – a five day spoken word festival; Fightin’ Words – poets in a boxing ring; The Poetburo Slams and the hyper- successful Word Up – a series of interstitial poetry spots airing on MuchMusic and Bravo! which spawned a CD with Virgin Records and an anthology with Key Porter. She was the poetry editor for Insomniac Press from 1999 to 2001. 

Jill is widely published across North America and the UK. Her first book, Hard Candy, was received to great acclaim and nominated for the Gerald Lampert Award. She has written several plays and solo works, including How I learned to live with obsession as well as Ecce Homo and Hard Candy – enhanced monologues for dance and voice. Jill has written the libretti for two short operas, Netsuke and Ashlike on the Cradle of the Wind, produced by Tapestry New Opera Works, and produced an electro acoustic sound art project, LinguaElastic, as part of the Canadian Music Centre’s New Music in New Places series. Dark Star Requiem, for which she wrote the libretto, premiered at Toronto’s Luminato Festival in June 2010. Her new project, Sleeptalker, will soon appear on stage. Jill’s third book of poems, Dark Star Requiem, was recently published by Folded & Gathered Press. Her new book, The Ecstatic Torture of Gratitude, has just been published by Guernica Editions. Gratitude Songs – a CD of selected poems set to music – is available as a free download from Bandcamp. jillbattson.bandcamp.com/album/gratitude-songs

jillspoetbureau.blogspot.com
225294861004922.location: The Ottawa Art Gallery |  La Galerie d'art d'Ottawa
225294861004922.name: CATHERINE OWEN & JILL BATTSON

226324190884245.description:
span-o (the small press action network - ottawa) presents:

    the ottawa
    small press
    book fair

spring 2014 edition
will be happening Saturday, June 7
in room 203 of the Jack Purcell Community Centre
(on Elgin, at 320 Jack Purcell Lane).

contact rob at rob_mclennan@hotmail.com to sign up for a table, etc.

"once upon a time, way way back in October 1994, rob mclennan & James Spyker invented a two-day event called the ottawa small press book fair, and held the first one at the National Archives of Canada..." Spyker moved to Toronto soon after our original event, but the fair continues, thanks in part to the help of generous volunteers, various writers and publishers, and the public for coming out to participate with alla their love and their dollars.

General info:

the ottawa small press book fair

noon to 5pm (opens at 11:00 for exhibitors)

admission free to the public.

$20 for exhibitors, full tables
$10 for half-tables
(payable to rob mclennan, c/o [NEW ADDRESS!] 2423 Alta Vista Drive, Ottawa ON K1H 7M9;

send by May 20 if you would like to appear in the exhibitor catalogue.

note: for the sake of increased demand, we are now offering half tables. for catalog, exhibitors should send name of press, address, email, web address, contact person, type of publications, list of publications (with price), if submissions are being considered & any other pertinent info, including upcoming ottawa-area events (if any).

& don't forget the pre-fair reading usually held the night before, info tba! also,

BE AWARE: given that the spring 2013 was the first to reach capacity (forcing me to say no to at least half a dozen exhibitors), the fair can't (unfortunately) fit everyone who wishes to participate. the fair is roughly first-come, first-served, but preference will be given to small publishers over self-published authors (being a "small press fair," after all).

the fair usually contains exhibitors with poetry books, novels,cookbooks, posters, t-shirts, graphic novels, comic books, magazines, scraps of paper, gum-ball machines with poems, 2x4s with text, etc, including (at previous events) Bywords, Dusty Owl, Chaudiere Books, above/ground press, Room 302 Books, The Puritan, The Ottawa Arts Review, Buschek Books, The Grunge Papers, Broken Jaw Press, BookThug, Proper Tales Press, Phafours Press, and others. happens twice a year, founded in 1994 by rob mclennan & James Spyker. now run by rob mclennan thru span-o. questions, rob_mclennan@hotmail.com

free things can be mailed for fair distribution to the same address. we are unable to sell things for folk who can't make it, sorry. also, always looking for volunteers to poster, move tables, that sort of thing. let me know if anyone able to do anything. thanks. for more information, bother rob mclennan.if you're able/willing to distribute posters/fliers for the fair, send me an email.

http://www.smallpressbookfair.blogspot.ca/2014/02/the-ottawa-small-press-fair-spring-2014.html
226324190884245.name: the ottawa small press fair, spring 2014 edition: june 7, 2014

228010100722728.description:
GATHERING SPARKS leads two music workshops at the Ottawa Folklore Centre on Saturday, April 12.

Slide Guitar OR Singing Harmony by Ear 
Saturday, April 12. 1-3 pm
Ottawa Folklore Centre
1111 Bank Street
$50 for members, $60 for non-members
http://www.ottawafolklore.com
613-730-2887

SLIDE GUITAR WORKSHOP
Taught by Sam Turton 

Playing guitar with a slide (a glass or metal tube) creates a unique and mesmerizing sound that you’ll hear from Robert Johnson to Jack White, delta blues to hard rock. Beginning with the basic use of the slide, we will explore right and left hand techniques, picking, muting, classic phrases, and basic tunings. Participants must be able to play basic chords comfortably. Some familiarity with playing single note phrases will also be helpful, but not required. Bring a slide and tuner with your guitar—extra slides will also be available. Slide on! Saturday April 12th, 1-3pm $50mem, $60non, WKSHP14.04s

SINGING HARMONY BY EAR
Taught by Jane Lewis and Eve Goldberg 

Have you ever wanted to sing harmony on the fly? In this workshop, you’ll learn how to listen for harmonies and how to find parts on your own. We’ll use exercises and songs to build confidence and give you a road map to help you find your harmonic way. This workshop is designed for all singers, though you should be able to sing the scale (do-re-mi-fa-sol-la-ti-do) and be fairly comfortable singing in a group. Saturday April 12th, 1-3pm $50mem, $60non, WKSHP14.04
228010100722728.name: Gathering Sparks Music Workshops at Ottawa Folklore Centre

Word/ Thought Balloon Mash-up! 

Mash Up Version #1:
The artist draws a comic panel and leaves the word balloons blank. The next artist gets to write in the words and then begins the next panel (with blank balloons). And so on!

Version #2
The artist draws a panel with ONLY the word/ thought balloons filled in. The next artist gets to fill in the characters in panel 1.Next, they get to write ONLY the word/ thought balloons for panel 2.

Version #3
Any cool variants people come up with on this mash-up theme. Open to suggestions!

Come and draw with other artists and writers in a convivial and creative environment!

231637333692435.description:
Join us for a 1-hour film about the challenges facing the Colombian Peace Community of San José de Apartadó. The film will be followed by a discussion of the situation in Colombia and the human rights concerns of Amnesty International. The event is free so spread the word! :)

Drinks, popcorn and desserts will also be available. All donations will go towards AI's work on behalf of the Peace Community of San José de Apartadó. There is free parking behind the AI Canada Office building off Russell Avenue.

About the documentary Hope for Colombia:

Hope for Colombia follows the 10 day Grace Pilgrimage through and around the Colombian capital Bogota in November 2010. It is a portrait of two projects – Tamera, a peace research centre in Portugal which organized the pilgrimage, and the Colombian peace community San José de Apartadó.

The film shows the coming together of the two communities, their encounters with other peace activists and groups in the city of Bogota, shanty towns and remote areas, and with government officials to create a network of protection for the peace community in Colombia and to show a possible path toward a global culture of peace in a seemingly hopeless situation.

"For the blindness of those who are murderers makes them unable to see that they can do what they want, there will always be community as long as pain turns into hope."
—Eduar Lanchero, peace community San José de Apartadó
231637333692435.name: Amnesty Movie Night: Hope for Colombia

231853057011521.description:
Dr. Donna Hicks will be speaking and responding to questions on her insightful and wise book, Dignity: The Essential Role it Plays in Resolving Conflict (Yale University Press 2013). It is a book that is both practical and profound -- aimed at resolving political and military conflicts, and yet which can apply equally well to conflicts in personal relations.

Dr. Hicks, from Harvard's Weatherhead Center for International Affairs, has over two decades of experience using dignity to resolve conflict, between people and nations, in the U.S., Columbia, Middle East, Sri Lanka, Cuba, and Northern Ireland. Among her many achievements was co-hosting with Archbishop Desmond Tutu the BBC show Facing the Truth, which brought victims and perpetrators of the Northern Ireland conflict together to find resolution.

In addition to sponsorship by the Harvard Alumni Association and the Harvard Club of Ottawa, her talk is a Edith Holtom Lecture, a series on the pursuit of peace sponsored by the First Unitarian Congregation of Ottawa. Among previous lecturers in this series have been Ed Broadbent and Flora MacDonald.  The sanctuary is itself a peaceful and dignified place in which to hold this lecture.  

Attendees are invited for refreshments after the talk.
For those who would like to read her book in advance, it is available online.  Some of the introduction can be downloaded free at http://goo.gl/8XHial

Net proceeds and donations from this event will be donated to the Collaborative Justice Program: Restorative Justice Ottawa (www.collaborativejustice.ca). This program was initiated by the Church Council on Justice and Corrections (CCJC), a national, ecumenical, bilingual charitable organization mandated to assist churches and communities to reflect on and more deeply engage issues in the field of criminal justice.

The link to purchase advance tickets ($20) is at  http://donnahicksmay8.eventbrite.ca or donate at the door.
231853057011521.location: First Unitarian Congregation of Ottawa 30 Cleary Ave Ottawa, ON K2A 3Z9 Canada
231853057011521.name: Harvard Club of Ottawa -- Donna Hicks on Dignity: Its Essential Role in Resolving Conflict

233329683529434.description:
May is Bike to Work month - 
May is also bus-pass-is-up month -
Solution: Ride your bike to school!!

As part of the VP Community Health representative for the upcoming year, I want to invite you all to Ride your Bike to school for May! This campaign is all about promoting cycling in our community! We want to advocate for cycling as a form of healthy active living, but also for injury prevention through cycling safety and awareness. Please join us!

If you don't have a bike - walk, run, skip - whatever suits your fancy. 

Fun Facts about Cycling in Ottawa
	- There are over 600km of bike paths in the national capital region 
	- OC-transpo busses have a "Rack and Roll" program - lets you take your bike with you from mid-April until October 31 each year. If you’re running late or catch a flat, you can hop on any of more than 350 buses equipped with front-mounted bikeracks.  You may also be allowed on the bus with your bike IF there is room. 
	- Cyclists are permitted to board the O-Train year-round.
	- There are several bike co-ops or reuse centres where you can find used bikes or bike parts such as:
		○ UOttawa Bike Coop - http://sfuo.ca/bikes/
		○ Re-Cycles Community Bicycle Shop - www.re-cycles.ca
		○ Recyclore - www.recyclore.org
	- "Ride the City Ottawa" has a website that will let you map out your route based on preference of "most direct", "safe" or "Safer" - www.ridethecity.com/ottawa
	
Events this month (and some more in the works…)
	- Sunday May 4th  - Group ride from RGN to main campus to familiarize with the bike route and road rules. 
	- Sunday May 11th - Group ride/ carpool to MEC BikeFest in Westboro
	- Potential Bike Maintenance 101 workshop - 1-2 hr session, pending interest from students.

Tips for riding in traffic
	- Wear a helmet - your brain is worth a lot, protect it. Pretty simple. 
	- You ARE a vehicle, thus you have the same RIGHTS and RESPONSIBILITIES
	- You ARE NOT a pedestrian, thus - don't ride on the sidewalks. You may, of course, WALK your bike on the sidewalk.
	- Be assertive but predictable. Stay out of cars' and ESPECIALLY trucks' blind-spots.
	- Take the space you need to feel safe, just because you are on a bike does not mean you have to ride through the crappy potholes and eroding shoulder.
	- Give yourself 1m space between you and parked cars/sidewalk.
	- Have a white front light and red rear light for riding at night. In fact, it's the law. 

If planning on biking, I strongly encourage everyone to review the following resources:
For signs and road markings:
http://ottawa.ca/en/residents/transportation-and-parking/cycling/signs-and-markings
For City of Ottawa Road Laws for Cyclists:http://ottawa.ca/en/residents/transportation-and-parking/cycling/cycling-and-law
233329683529434.name: UOttawa Meds Bike to School Month

233334300196601.description:
It's that time.

The weather should be good. The apartment is in order. And now it begins.

This party is themed! Think Mad Men. Think That 70's Show. Think... what your parents did of an evening now and then back in the 60s and 70s. It's a cocktail party! An evening social to kick back, relax and chat with friends both old and new. A night to strut your stuff. 

There IS a dress code. Suits... ties and jackets. Dresses. I don't care what gender you are underneath your clothing but please DO dress up for it. Feel fancy. Get your gorgeous on. Will I turn you away if you show up in jeans and tshirt? Newp... I shan't... but I will adore you all the more if you dress for the occasion.

This is an evening event so no 'family afternoon hour' unfortunately, which means if you gots kids you'll need to arrange a babysitter. 

Bring your own alcohol. Munchies will occur. Music will be provided. Interesting and intriguing people will be in attendance.

Note: there will be a smoking room in the back for those what smoke tobacco. Please, only tobacco. There are no pets for those with allergies.

For those what have not been here before, it's Apartment 4. No buzz code, just press the button marked '4' at the front door. There is street parking and the location is about two long blocks from Billings Bridge, serviced by several busses. It is one flight up from the ground floor.

234060030121322.description:
To celebrate summer, come out for reading by three great writers! Karen Dudley and Robin Riopelle have new novels out and Scott Fotheringham  is the author of the acclaimed novel THE REST IS SILENCE.

KAREN DUDLEY didn’t know she was supposed to be a writer, so she studied everything from Greek history to ecology to Quaternary pollen analysis. Then she wrote a short stack of wildlife biology books and four environmental mystery novels before she decided that maybe she should be writing fantasy. Her first fantasy, Food for the Gods, was nominated for five awards including an Prix Aurora award for Best Science Fiction and Fantasy Novel, a Bony Blithe Bloody Words Light Mystery award, and a High Plains book award in the Culinary Division. She will be reading from Kraken Bake, the newly-published sequel to Food for the Gods.

Born in Ottawa and raised on Canada’s west coast, ROBIN RIOPELLE’s life has been marked by adoption, separation, and reunion. Like many of her characters, she has a muddy past and a foot in (at least) two different worlds. She currently lives on the border between French and English Canada with her criminologist husband, two seemingly delightful children, and an obstreperous spaniel. She is a great supporter of the Oxford comma.

In addition to writing fiction for adults, Riopelle also illustrates children’s books. Deadroads is her first novel.


SCOT T FOTHERINGHAM holds a PhD in molecular biology and genetics from Cornell University. He has co-authored scientific articles on molecular genetics, and closely studied the mechanisms of recombination using genetically engineered fungi, bacteria, and fruit flies. His first novel, The Rest Is Silence, was short-listed for the Amazon First Novel Award, Dartmouth Book Award, and an Ottawa Book Award. Raised in Thornhill, Scott now lives and writes just outside Ottawa where he is working on his second novel.
234060030121322.name: ChiSeries Ottawa Presents: Karen Dudley, Robin Riopelle and Scott Fotheringham

238666919590394.description:
Tuesday, April 8, 7-8:30pm - University of Ottawa (Faculty of Social Sciences Building FSS4006)

Prominent Honduran human rights activist Bertha Oliva, general coordinator of the Committee of Relatives of the Disappeared and Detained in Honduras (COFADEH), will be speaking in Toronto, Six Nations, Ottawa and Montreal the week of April 7 to 11, 2014

Join us for a discussion with Bertha Oliva, to hear about the post-election human rights situation in Honduras and how Honduran organizations like hers are responding. 
Karen Spring (Honduras Solidarity Network - HSN) will talk about the work of the HSN and shed light on the impact of Canadian investment in Honduras' tourism sector on Garifuna communities. 
Jen Moore (Mining Watch Canada) will talk about the effects of Canadian mining in Honduras and initiatives that are seeking to address these challenges.

A coup in 2009, as well as controversial elections in November 2013, deemed fraudulent by most independent elections observers, have shaken Honduras in recent years. Despite several democratic setbacks, as well as an escalated climate of violence and repression in Honduras, the Canadian government has only deepened its political support for, as well as economic ties with the Central American country. A trade deal between Canada and Honduras, signed in November 2013 and currently being pushed through parliament, risks exacerbating an already dire situation, putting investor rights head of community rights.

Hosted by the Americas Policy Group (Canadian Council for International Cooperation), PSAC Social Justice Fund and Canadian Union of Public Employees.

This is part of the Building Solidarity with Honduras Tour: Peoples' Rights over Corporate Rights. More details can be found at: http://www.commonfrontiers.ca/tour-2014 Follow the tour on Twitter at #hondurassolidarity.
238666919590394.name: Canadian Policies, Corporate Interests and Human Rights in Honduras

244673242373030.description:
Gnarly Conspiracy On The Road est fier d'ouvrir la saison 2014 avec notre première longue distance: Montréal-Ottawa, plus de 200km en une seule journée.

Les cycliste devront être en forme physiquement et mentalement prêt à faire toute la ride. Préparez vous à vous pousser sur plus de 200km!

Assurez vous de faire un bon check up sur votre vélo avant la ride pour éviter des problèmes. Pneus prêts à rouler bien gonflés, chaine graissée, go-pro installée, etc.

Le voyage inclus:

-Camionette de support pour nos bagages et urgence
-Mécanique de vélo et outils (tubes et pneus disponible à un prix minimal)
-Petite séance d'étirement après la ride
-Hébergement et déjeuner
-Activité de groupe à Ottawa
-Billet de retour en bus

Le prix du voyage reste à déterminer, nous travaillons fort à négocier les prix du transport et de l'hébergement.!

HELMET IS MANDATORY!

La ride:
http://goo.gl/maps/eIRX1

Nous dormons à Ottawa et nous revenons dimanche le 4 mai en soirée 

Pourquoi? 
Parce que l'on aime rouler jusqu'à ce que ce soit le mental qui embarque.

-------------------------------------------------

Gnarly Conspiracy On The Road is proud to start the 2014 season with our first ride Montréal to Ottawa in one day over 200km.

This is a great way to start the season, the cyclists participating will have to be in good shape to push it over 200 km.

Your bike has to be in good shape in order to go trough the trip without a problem, recommendation is to have a good bike check-up done before the trip.

The trip will include:

-support Van to bring all our baggage  
-bike mechanic and tools (tubes and tires will be available at a minimal charge)
-small stretching class after the ride 
-hostel and breakfast 
-activity as a group in Ottawa
-ticket back home on either bus, train or support van.

The trip will cost 90$/person.

LE CASQUE EST OBLIGATOIRE!

The ride:
http://goo.gl/maps/eIRX1

We sleep at Ottawa and we will come back on night of May 4th.

More info to come.

Our goal is to get you on a bike, until the mental kicks in. Gnarly Conspiracy

247521002100894.description:
INVITE YOUR MP  - Help get the message to our MPs re: May 6th 2014!  

Links to poster -  

http://climatefast.ca/sites/default/files/files/D4%20Do%20Math%20Ottawa.pdf

http://climatefast.ca/sites/default/files/images/Do%20the%20Math%20Ott


On May 6 ClimateFast is hosting a screening of Do the Math, a movie made by 350.org. The film makes it very clear why we must start making the transition to renewable energy right now, not in thirty years. Our MPs need to know this. You can be a big help!

Please take two minutes to either download the poster(PDF) or send the link for the May 6th event to your MP telling them that you hope they will mark their calendar and attend. Tell them why it is important to you. If your MP is francophone, there is the French version of the poster (PDF).

Your e-mail letter could look like this:

Dear MP,

I am writing to ask you and your staff to attend this screening of Do the Math in Ottawa on May 6th: It is important to me that you and all MP’s become as informed as possible on climate change and what we must do.
247521002100894.name: Do the Math screening in Ottawa - Invite your MP

251252005050395.description:
Please pre-register / Svp inscrivez-vous
via Eventbrite:
http://www.eventbrite.com/e/great-cloth-diaper-change-ottawagatineau-tickets-10215180881?aff=efbevent

(scroll down for english) C’est notre première année en tant qu’hôte du Grand Changement de Couches Lavables et nous espérons que vous nous joindrez pour battre un record Guinness! On se fera reconnaitre à Gatineau/Ottawa! (voire plus bas pour plus de détails) 

This is our first year organizing a local Great Cloth Diaper Change event and we hope you'll join us in setting a new Guinness World record! Let's put Ottawa/Gatineau on the map! (See below for more details)

Le Grand changement de couches lavables est un évènement amusant pour réunir les parents en célébration et promotion des couches lavables! L’an dernier le nouveau record était de 8301 couches lavables change a la même heure a 182 endroits dans 15 pays! On espère battre ce record cette année!

L’évènement sera aussi une levée de fond pour le RDA (Real Diaper Association - http://www.realdiaperassociation.org/). Le RDA c’est le fondateur et organisateur du Grand changement et une merveilleuse organisation pour la promotion des couches lavables.

Pour participe il faut avoir 18 ans et accompagner un enfant de moins de 39 pouces. C’est tout! Pas nécessaire de déjà utiliser les couches lavables et pas nécessaire que l’enfant arrive en couches lavables. Si vous n’avez pas une couche lavable, ou ne pouvez pas en emprunter, une peut vous être prêté pour la durée de l’évènement. Si vous apportez votre propre couche svp notez que seulement les couches disponibles commercialement qualifie pour le record mondial (règlements de Guinness) alors malheureusement les couches maison ne peuvent pas qualifié.

Svp planifier d’arrive tôt. Les portes ouvrent à 10h00 et le changement aura lieu à 11:00 exacte. Svp ne pas hésitez de me contacter avec n’importe quel question!

 This is a fun event designed to get cloth diapering parents together to celebrate and promote cloth diapers! Last year the new world record was set at 8,301 cloth diapers changed at one time at 182 qualifying locations in 15 countries! We're hoping to beat that this year!

 We'll also be collecting donations for the RDA (Real Diaper Association - http://www.realdiaperassociation.org/ ), the founders and organizers of the Great Cloth Diaper Change and a wonderful non-profit organization set up for the promotion and support of cloth diapers.

 You must be 18 years of age and have a child under 39 inches in order to participate! That's it, couldn't be simpler! You do not need to currently use cloth diapers and your child does not even need to show up wearing a cloth diaper. If you don't own, or can't borrow a cloth diaper, one will be loaned to you at the event. If you do bring your own diaper, please note that in order to qualify for the record the diaper must be available commercially (Guinness rules) so unfortunately homemade diapers do not qualify.

 Please be sure to arrive early, we'll start registering people at 10am with the official change happening at 11am sharp. Feel free to contact me at karen@amotherstouch.ca with any questions.
251252005050395.location: Legion Royal Canadienne, 59 Brancroft, Aylmer, QC, J9H 4N6
251252005050395.name: Great Cloth Diaper Change Ottawa/Gatineau

252113154975135.description:
INVITATION À UNE MARCHE MANIFESTATION
DES BURUNDAISES ET DES BURUNDAIS DU CANADA
Où : Colline du Parlement du Canada à Ottawa
Quand: Le 10 mai 2014 à 13H

La Diaspora Burundaise à Ottawa-Gatineau invite toutes les Burundaises et les Burundais du Québec et de l’Ontario à une grande manifestation baptisée : «Marchons pour la paix au Burundi».
Motifs de la manifestation :
La situation sociale actuelle au Burundi est très bonne du point de vue de la cohabitation entre les diverses composantes de la société. Elle est également très bonne du point de vue sécuritaire sur l’ensemble du territoire national. La réconciliation entre les composantes ethniques et politiques du pays, amorcée depuis 2005, progresse d’une façon positive.
La situation politique de ces derniers mois a pourtant été marquée par un climat de suspicion alimenté par certains burundais et étrangers aux intentions douteuses, qui sont allés jusqu’à brandir le spectre d’un prétendu génocide imminent. Voulant attiser la haine du passée entre les Burundais, leurs motifs ne sont pas encore connus quoique l’on puisse présumer qu’ils éprouvent des difficultés à gagner du terrain auprès de l’électorat burundais.
Notre marche pour la paix vise à dénoncer ce comportement et à souligner l’évolution positive du Burundi vers la paix et la réconciliation. Venez donc nombreux et «marchons pour la paix au Burundi» !
Thèmes de la manifestation
- Nous refusons que la Diaspora burundaise à travers le monde et les Burundais de l’intérieur soient instrumentalisés par certains politiciens et des étrangers au risque de mettre en danger les acquis de la démocratie au Burundi
- Nous refusons l’usage biaisé et abusif du mot génocide sur le Burundi, ni par les Nations Unies ni par certains acteurs politiques burundais
- Nous réitérons vivement notre soutien à toutes les actions positives du gouvernement burundais
- Nous disons OUI à la CNTB pour réhabiliter les sinistrés et rapatriés burundais dans leurs droits
- OUI à un BNUB impartial
- OUI à l’aide internationale pour le développement par les partenaires internationaux
- VIVE le Burundi qui contribue à l’établissement de l’État de Droit dans certaines parties du monde (Somalie, République Centre-Africaine, Haïti, Soudan du Sud)
- NON aux sabotages, aux paralysies des actions gouvernementales
- Oui à la démocratie qui est le gouvernement du peuple,par le peuple et pour le peuple
- Nous disons PLUS JAMAIS les coups d’État et les massacres comme en 1965, 1972, 1988, 1993 !!!
- OUI à une société civile apolitique et impartiale
- NON à l’ingérence extérieure

Fait à Ottawa le 26-04-2014
Pour les organisateurs de la manifestation:
Ernest Mbanzendore et David Daudi Niyonsaba Niyomwungere
252113154975135.name: MARCHE-MANIFESTATION À OTTAWA

Ottawa Central is pleased to be having their 2nd semi-annual sale Saturday May 24th & Sunday May 25th at the RA Centre.

Saturday May 24th 10am-3:00pm 
Sunday May 25th 10:00am-2:00pm*
*50% off marked items

Want to be a part of Canada's Largest Children’s consignment sale?

There are 4 ways you can participate.

1) Consign! – Consignors earn 65-80% on the gently used items that they sell! Easy online signup. You set the prices on your stuff! Print your tags and manage your inventory from the comfort of your home! Consignors receive a Pre-Sale Extravaganza Pass. You get to SHOP the sale before the public!

2) Shop! – Looking to save BIG? Shop & Save 50% - 90% off retail! You will find amazing deals on everything your kids need this spring/summer. We never know exactly what items will show up at each sale, but if kids use it, we are likely to have it :)

3) Volunteer! - Our 3 hour volunteer shifts are easy and NO experience is needed. You do not need to be a consignor to volunteer to shop the Pre-Sale EXTRAVAGANZA.
If you consign AND volunteer your earn an extra 5% PLUS you get to shop earlier!

4) Showcase your product or service! – What better way to reach Hundreds of Ottawa and area families? If your business has a product or service that is geared towards families we want to hear from you! Early bird rate is in effect until May1st.

Full Event Details Available Online: http://ottawa.outgrowoutplay.com/

Admission is a donation to the Ottawa Food Bank in lieu of $2.00

BeautiControl offers you unmatched training and personal growth opportunities to be your best. BeautiYOU® Training—your day of professional training—is where the fun begins. This exclusive service sets BeautiControl apart from the competition. Join other new Consultants to experience the excitement, energy and enthusiasm of BeautiControl for the first time. You’ll have fun making new friends, learning about skin care and holding Spas, and getting your business started.

A team of carefully selected and trained BeautiControl National Trainers conducts training classes in cities across the United States, Puerto Rico, and Canada. You’ll find out how others like you have earned money, trips, jewelry, and other rewards and built successful careers! You’ll want to experience this unmatched training experience as soon as possible so be sure to attend BeautiU Training within your first 90 days so you can take advantage of the special opportunities available only at BeautiYOU.

At BeautiYOU, you can:

•Discover your own M. R. P. daily facial regimen, and experience products to use and share
•Bring guests with you to invite them to join you in your BeautiContol business
•Learn how to hold successful Spas to build your business
•Learn about the products and services that set BeautiControl Independent Consultants apart from the competition
•Learn to put into motion the dynamic, field-proven Magic Success Formula, build a substantial client base and earn profit within days
•Take advantage of the ordering opportunities for new Consultants available only at BeautiYOU when you attend within your first 90 days
•Discover how to capitalize on the power of professional training to build a personal team of new Consultants, advance to higher career levels, qualify for higher ordering discounts, and make more money right away

All Consultants are encouraged to bring up to 3 guests to BeautiYOU to introduce them to BeautiControl. It’s a great way to engage prospects in starting their own BeautiControl business.

•After you register, go to BeautiYOU registration and click on “registration details”
•Attend BeautiYOU with your guests to help them feel comfortable and receive credit when they do sign up as a new Consultant
•Registering your guests online, or with the Care Center, ensures them a seat and BeautiYOU materials

We can’t wait to see you at your BeautiYOU Training! Arrive promptly and prepare to graduate as a Certified BeautiControl Consultant.

•Bring the BeautiBook from your Spa Now Case.
•Please bring a sweater or jacket, as the meeting facilities may be cold.
•Be prepared to take advantage of incredible ordering opportunities and special offers, available only at BeautiYOU!

Note: you must register for BeautiYOU on BeautiNet or by calling our Consultant Care Centre at 1-800-943-8084.

Jerry, and his band the Situation (James McKie, Dan Mock, Kyle Sullivan) organist Jeff Heisholt, Aaron Comeau on piano and backup vocalists (Carleigh Aikins, Tamara Lindeman, Ivy Mairi) recorded Early Riser, already album number seven in a remarkably young career. It’s the first to be produced by Michael Timmins of Cowboy Junkies, a man who unquestionably knows his way around a song. Jerry’s been building such alliances more and more lately; one of his earliest supporters was Ron Sexsmith, who’s played piano on a couple of Jerry’s previous albums, including the last, Some Folks Know. That record also featured a duet with Serena Ryder, and after his first trip to Nashville, Jerry now counts Jim Lauderdale and other Music City luminaries among his fans.

263057597222456.description:
La Petite Mort Gallery & The Embassy of Mexico, Ottawa present

MEXICAN MASKS FROM THE MUYAES OGAZóN COLLECTION 1940-1980.

JUNE 13 - 26, 2014 / VERNISSAGE Friday June 13 / 7 - 10pm @ La Petite Mort Gallery / 306 Cumberland Street / Ottawa

Please come meet the Ambassador of Mexico in Ottawa, Canada who will say a brief speech.

Organized by Soileh Padilla, Cultural Attache to the Embassy of Mexico, & Guy Berube, director of La Petite Mort Gallery.

 
Statement:

In the frame of celebrating 70 years of bilateral relations between Mexico and Canada, The Embassy of Mexico and La Petite Mort Gallery are proud to present this exhibition that shows a variety of masks from different regions of Mexico, it allows us to see the incredible variety that even for a lot of the Mexican people is unknown. There are masks from the States of Hidalgo, Guerrero, Chiapas, Puebla, Jalisco, Sonora , Nayarit, Queretaro, Guanajuato, Michoacán and other places that somehow have survived the accelerated pace of the country. We see animals that transform the dancer into a fierce tiger or a shy rabbit ,we see moors and Christians that are loaded with the religious background imposed to the Mexican people in colonial times, and other characters full of humor, anguish , desire, happiness, guilt, and any other human vulnerability that can be expressed through this fantastic form of art.

The Muyaes Ogazon collection of traditional Mexican masks was put together by Professor Estela Ogazon and the anthropologist Jaled Muyaes throughout more than 50 years. They dedicated their lives to the rescue of Mexican culture emphasizing their energy in the fascinating world of the Mexican dances and celebrations which use masks. The collection is composed by about 3000 masks all of which have been used in the celebrations which makes them unique pieces filled with a life of their own. They focused specially in the aesthetics of the objet but always made sure to have all the ethnographic information that a serious collection requires.
They travelled all over Mexico ,attended the celebrations in the small towns, some at Christmas time, some at Easter, others celebrating the Patron saint of the communities, some other ritual, like in the State of Nayarit and Sonora. But always regarding these festivities with great respect and admiration, praising the traditions that have lasted throughout centuries and that other countries like the one this collection is visiting now, have to offer to the world.

Our indigenous people have defended their traditions with passion, they show us what we are with their incredibly artistic expressions like the masks, where we come from and where we could go with their legacy. 

Our legacy.

See more: http://www.lapetitemortgallery.com/embassy-of-mexico-june-2014/

 

                                     Gracias.
263057597222456.name: La Petite Mort Gallery﻿ & The Embassy of Mexico (Ottawa) present  MEXICAN MASKS FROM THE MUYAES OGAZóN COLLECTION 1940-1980.

TICKETS ON SALE NOW!
Ottawa, are you ready for the biggest and greatest CHIVE meet up ever?
We've linked up with probably the most Canadian venues in Ottawa, and are going to fill the streets on the 22nd of March 2014, to help raise funds for Chive Charities!
What are we talking about? Try this on for size;
At 8pm, we are starting a pub crawl through 3 of the best venues in the Byward Market! For any of you who were on our last one, well, you know how ludicrous we get! There will be drink specials at every spot!
START POINT:
8-9pm PUB 101
9-10pm The Cabin
10-11pm The Whiskey
Then at 11pm, we move to the main event! In probably the most Canadian and craziest bar in CANADA, Johnny McBeauty's!
We're going to have shirts, we're going to have prizes, there will be giveaways (you might have to earn one though), there will be drink specials, and always we're going to blow the roof off raising a glass for charity!
PRICES:
PUB CRAWL: $10 
MAIN EVENT: $5 online, $6 at the door
And as you know, the meet up tickets go fast, so stay posted as we announce the details, and when and where you can get tickets, we've got a few things planned!
WHAT DO I NEED TO DO?
Purchase either a Pub Crawl Ticket or Main Event ticket. Make sure to fill out the names of each attendee if purchasing multiple tickets!

IF I PURCHASE A PUB CRAWL TICKET, DO I HAVE TO PURCHASE A MAIN EVENT TICKET?
No, the Pub Crawl ticket is good for entrance to the Meet up as well. 

DO I NEED TO BRING THE TICKET WITH ME?
Yes, you need to bring a printed version of the ticket sent in your confirmation email (PDF), or your cell phone with the PDF on it. If you're coming to the pub crawl, you'll ned to exchange it for a wristband.

WHAT TIME IS THE PUB CRAWL?
It starts at 8pm, so be there a little earlier to make sure you get your wrist band!

WHAT TIME IS THE MAIN EVENT?
Doors will open at 11:00pm! 

WHAT IS AT THE MAIN EVENT?
Door Prizes (to be announced!)
Drink Specials
Limited Tees!
One wicked awesome DJ
And just a whole lot more!

CAN I PURCHASE A TEE BEFORE THE PUB CRAWL OR EVENT?
YOU CAN GET A TEE ONLINE AT OUR WEBSITE OR IN LIMITED NUMBERS AT THE EVENT. KCCO
You can purchase tees online at our website until the event. We cannot guarantee you will have them for the event.

HOW DO I GET UPDATES AS THE EVENT GETS CLOSER?
Follow us on our social media, and check back here for updates!

This session is beginner/intermediate and will be 10 weeks long. Everyone will have an option to perform the routine that we will be learning at our upcoming Summer Party on June 22nd, which is a Sunday.
Everyone has an option to sign up for the first 6 weeks of the session first, and then decide whether to continue into the remainder of the session. The cost for the first 6 weeks of the session is $90. And the cost for the total 10-weeks session is $150.

273209296171706.description:
Join us for the launch of Min Fami: Arab Feminist Reflections on Identity, Space, and Resistance (Inanna Publications), an exciting new anthology edited by Ghadeer Malek and Ghaida Moussa, featuring over 30 contributor's poetry, short stories, critical reflections, academic work, and visual art by Arab feminists from across the world.

We are coming to Ottawa to celebrate the release of the book after 3 years of heart, soul, longing, (and lots of long nights!). 

Along with selected readings from the book, the evening will include special guest performances by Myron and Sibylle Rym Ben Berrah, and Maha Zimmo! No Arab celebration would be complete without good food and good conversation!

This event is free, and all are welcome!

Accessibility Note:

Venus Envy is wheelchair accessible.
Seating is limited but there will be standing room, and some floor seating, but let us know if you need a seat reserved.
If there are any ways we can make this event more accessible to you, please let us know as soon as you can by calling 613 789 4646.

More about the book:

Min Fami: Arab Feminist Reflections on Identity, Space, and Resistance is an anthology that cradles the thoughts of Arab feminists, articulated through personal critical narratives, academic essays, poetry, short stories, and visual art. It is a meeting space where discussions on home(land), exile, feminism, borders, gender and sexual identity, solidarity, language, creative resistance, and (de)colonization are shared, confronted, and subverted. In a world that has increasingly found monolithic and one-dimensional ways of representing Arab womyn, this anthology comes as an alternate space in which we connect on the basis of our shared identities, despite physical, theoretical, and metaphorical distances, to celebrate our multiple voices, honour our ancestry, and build community on our own terms, and in our own voices. Pre-order is now available online: https://www.inanna.ca/index.php/catalog/min-fami-arab-feminist-reflections-identity-space-and-resistance/

About the editors:

Ghadeer Malek is a Palestinian feminist activist, aspiring writer and spoken word poet. She immigrated to Toronto in 2003 to study at the University of Toronto and graduated with an honours bachelor degree in History and Middle Eastern studies after which she joined the Association of Women’s Right in Development (AWID). She currently coordinates the Young Feminist Activism (YFA) Program at AWID and is pursuing a Master’s degree at OISE/UT. Ghadeer is also a co-founder and editor of Aqsazine, an art collective of young progressive and critical Muslim women passionate about combating gender-based violence through art. Ghadeer’s poetry has been published in Feminism for real and Shameless Magazine. 

Ghaida Moussa is a scholar, educator, and dj, who is passionately drawn to creative articulations of resistance, identity, memory, and space. She holds a bi-disciplinary Master’s degree in International Development and Global Studies, and Women’s Studies from the University of Ottawa. She is currently undertaking her Ph.D. in Social and Political Thought at York University in Toronto, Canada. The past couple of years, she has been devoted to translating anti-colonial notions onto dance floors, thinking through “home” in the cracks between anchored locations and collective memory, and practicing pedagogy from the heart in the classroom and in alternate spaces of education.


About the performers:

Rym Ben Berrah, Sibylle de surnom, est une étudiante en autisme et en psychologie. Originaire de l'Afrique du Nord, Tuniso-Algérienne, elle est arrivée à Montréal durant son adolescence et partage le reste de sa vie entre Ottawa, Montréal et nouvellement Toronto. Récipiendaire de nombreux prix d'écriture de nouvelles, de slam et de théâtre, elle se spécialise dans l'art de la scène depuis 2008. Ses inspirations sont diverses, mais le tout est sibyllin, rythmé de douceur et de véracité.

Maha Zimmo family came to Canada when she was aged four and still malleable to her parents' will. They are Muslim, Palestinian and she was born in Libya; essentially, her identity is where all Axis of Evil points converse. March 29th marks her ten year anniversary as writer at / owner of Prolific Immigrant (onefemalecanuck.com); she has completed Middle Eastern news analysis for several progressive news teams such as Rabble. She is currently the resident 'Know-It-All' advice columnist at both Elle Beaver - where Canadian feminists discuss issues and challenge one another, and everyone else - and at Chai Latte Diaries.
273209296171706.name: Book Launch for MIN FAMI at Venus Envy Ottawa

274490446046149.description:
Celebrate your love for wax on this vinyl-filled weekend and join us at the First Ever International Record Swap Day in Ottawa!

Everyone is welcome at this free event. Even if you don't have records to swap, come listen to records and have fun with us anyway!

April 18th, the day before Record Store Day, is an ideal time to make some room on your record shelves for an update to music your collection.  Dig out your doubles, your old, neglected records and put aside some rare gems that you want to trade for other rare gems.  Any vinyl record format (7", 10", 12") is welcome.

This will be a barter only event, so no money exchange for records.  You can trade 1 for 1, 1 for 3, or whatever is fair, as long as both parties are satisfied with the trade. 
If you have records that may be unworthy of a trade, why not bring them to give away for free?  

7 - 9pm: Show up with your records to trade, listen to music, relax and have a drink!

9pm - 2am: Record swap ends, DJ party begins with Ottawa's finest….

274823446026829.description:
Families of Sister in Spirit (FSIS) is a grassroots not-for-profit volunteer organization located on unceded Algonquin Territory (Ottawa) led by families of missing and murdered Indigenous women,girls, two spirit and trans people with support from Indigenous and non-Indigenous allies. In this talk, FSIS will discuss more in depth about the work that they have done, as well as the recent statement that is critical of state led intervention. http://nationsrising.org/it-starts-with-us/

--- SPEAKERS ---

Bridget Tolley is Algonquin grandmother from the Kitigan Zibi Anishinabeg in Quebec, Canada. Her mother Gladys Tolley was struck and killed by a police car in October 2001. Bridget is a committed activist in the family-led movement to end violence and the disappearances and murders of Indigenous women and girls. She is also active in social justice causes causes related to police violence (a founding member of the Justice for the Victims of Police Killings Coalition in Montreal), Indigenous education, housing and child welfare..

Colleen Cardinal is a Plains Cree woman from Saddle Lake First Nation, AB. Colleen organizes with the grassroots volunteer group Families of Sisters in Spirit (FSIS). She speaks publicly and candidly about murdered and missing Indigenous women and the impacts of the 60’s Scoop drawing critical connections between genocidal colonial policies and her lived experiences and those of women in her family. She believes that sharing her story is an important part of her healing journey in addition to raising awareness and building solidarity and understanding within Indigenous and non-Indigenous communities. Colleen strongly believes in supporting/upholding women's self-determination, including meeting them where they are at.

Kristen Gilchrist self-identifies as a queer non-Indigenous woman with Scottish, Welsh, French-Canadian and Ojibway relations, living on unsurrendered Anishinaabe aki (Algonquin lands). She’s working on a doctorate in sociology at Carleton University, is a survivor of sexual violence(s), former (and likely future) sex trader and, co-founder of Families of Sisters in Spirit (FSIS). 

Free!

Venus Envy is all on one level including the front door and bathroom. We do not have an automatic door.

277105315789004.description: The Modern Knowledge Tour  will be traveling across Canada combining unique speakers and their vast knowledge and experience of interlacing disciplines, blending their vision into a unique, interactive experience. The concepts and ideas presented in this tour will not only empower individuals to think for themselves, but also inspire them to ask questions regarding our current knowledge, doctrines,  and dogmas. Beginning with the earliest record of humanity, bridging the chasm of time and civilizations, and ending in today's severed society, the Modern Knowledge Tour will destroy the stubborn ideologies that have taken hold of today's human. A collection of some of the worlds best 'alternative researchers' and speakers, the Modern Knowledge Canada 2014 Tour will be an event that will shape our future direction as a species on this beautiful planet, and in our universe. We hope that all of you enjoy and experience the information presented within this tour, and find it both beneficial and inspiring. We look forward to meeting you on the road! .  The Modern Knowledge Tour is owned and operated in Canada!

282436161916041.description:
Jane’s Talk // Neighbourhood Narratives
Thursday, May 1
7 p.m. // Programme begins at 7:30 p.m.
Arts Court, 2 Daly Ave.
FREE

Join Jane’s Walk Ottawa for our kick-off event - Jane’s Talk 2014: Neighbourhood Narratives, with emcee and CBC host Adrian Harewood. Three local storytellers explore the intersection of memory, emotion, and change in neighbourhoods across Ottawa. We will hear from Centretown’s David O’Meara, award-winning poet, flaneur and bartender at local institution, the Manx Pub; Dennis Van Staalduinen, who will bring to life the stories contained in oak trees that are the living monuments of his neighbourhood, Champlain Park; and Alain Miguelez, an urban planner for the city and author of a book on the Ottawa’s all-but-forgotten cinemas.

Before the storytelling begins, come experience “Ottawa in One Room,” a video installation by local artists Jessica Aylsworth and Jon Booth. Their work evokes the shared memories of strangers as viewers are immersed in a whimsical space filled with scenes of Ottawa neighbourhoods projected onto floating panels of translucent fabric.

Join us afterwards to share treats and your own tales of Neighbourhood Narratives!

Jane’s Talk 2014: Neighbourhood Narratives is made possible through the generosity of the Downtown Rideau Business Improvement Area.

Jane's Walk Ottawa, a festival of 50+ free, citizen-led walking tours, takes place May 3-4. See the schedule at: http://www.janeswalkottawa.ca/sessions/4

"Ottawa in One Room" will be on all weekend, so visit Arts Court throughout Jane's Walk to check out the installation, grab some refreshment an hang out at Arts Court - the 2014 hub for Jane's Walk!

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Speakers:

Jessica Aylsworth is a multi-media artist. Her work focuses on drawing and fabric, but has increasingly been blending a wider range of mediums and genres, weaving together drawing, fabric, photography, projection, sound, and more. Her collaborator, Jon Booth, is self-taught sound artist. He has created pieces ranging from orchestral arrangements to piano rags to more abstract sound compositions. Although they work in very different mediums, they both like to explore the concepts of memory and identity in their works.

David O'Meara is the author of four collections of poetry, including most recently “A Pretty Sight” and a play, “Disaster,” nominated for four Rideau Awards. His poetry has been shortlisted for the Gerald Lampert Award, the ReLit Award, the Trillium Book Award, a National Magazine Award, and he has won the Archibald Lampman Award twice. He is the director of the Plan 99 Reading Series, Artistic Director of VERSEFest and was the Canadian judge for the 2012 Griffin Poetry Prize.

Fourth-year Jane’s Walk leader Dennis Van Staalduinen once thought that his neighbourhood of Champlain Park was boring, until a series of encounters with real living remnants of history led him to dig deeper, and learn much more about the characters, the urban planning choices, and the ancient Champlain Oak trees around him.

Alain Miguelez is an urban planner with the City of Ottawa and the author of A Theatre Near You.  Alain lives in Sandy Hill and has lived there, off and on, since his teenage years.  He likes that it’s such a good walking neighbourhood, that it’s close to everything, has nice old buildings, and that it’s so alive with the youthful energy of students.
282436161916041.name: Jane's Talk Ottawa 2014: Neighbourhood Narratives

Want to be a part of Canada's Largest Children’s consignment sale?

There are 4 ways you can participate.

1) Consign! – Consignors earn 65-80% on the gently used items that they sell! Easy online signup. You set the prices on your stuff! Print your tags and manage your inventory from the comfort of your home! Consignors receive a Pre-Sale Extravaganza Pass. You get to SHOP the sale before the public!

2) Shop! – Looking to save BIG? Shop & Save 50% - 90% off retail! You will find amazing deals on everything your kids need this spring/summer. We never know exactly what items will show up at each sale, but if kids use it, we are likely to have it :)

3) Volunteer! - Our 3 hour volunteer shifts are easy and NO experience is needed. You do not need to be a consignor to volunteer to shop the Pre-Sale EXTRAVAGANZA.

300642790090766.description:
UmmahHub in partnership with Muslim Link & the Carleton Centre for the Study of Islam invites you to a screening of the documentary Unmosqued.

UnMosqued explores the current state of how many US mosques are operating and the growing number of Muslim Americans feeling unwelcome in their mosques or un-mosqued. 
 
With reflections from Muslim educators such as Suhaib Webb, Nouman Ali Khan, and Waleed Basyouni, and informed by statistics from The American Mosque Study of 2011 co-commissioned by the Islamic Society of North America (ISNA), the documentary covers a range of topics from support for converts to the relevance of khutbahs to everyday life, women’s presence in mosques, and the role of mosque boards. 
 
The film also follows the journey of a diverse group of men and women committed to building a more inclusive community who have come together in an attempt to win seats on their mosque board.
 
After the screening, there will be a facilitated audience discussion on how we in Ottawa-Gatineau can address similar issues we may be experiencing in our own religious spaces in a way that is respectful, constructive, and focused on strengthening our community, not dividing it. 
 
 
Screening will be held at the River Building at the Carleton University.

Tickets are $10 for students and $12 for adults. Please purchase them in advance on Eventbrite as seating is limited.
 
Schedule:
1:30pm      Doors Open
1:45pm      Film Screening
3:00pm      Community Discussion


Social media marketing is provided by FWD MVMNT
300642790090766.name: Unmosqued Comes to Ottawa: Documentary Screening and Discussion

The Ottawa Arts Review, uOttawa's English-language lit and visual arts review, is hiring a new volunteer staff for the 2014/15 term! All positions are open for application, and they are as follows:

Editor-in-Chief 
Associate Editor
Editorial Assistant
Director of Submissions
Events Co-ordinator
Distributions Co-ordinator
Productions and Website Co-ordinator

In addition, we are always looking for volunteers to fill our reader positions!

If you have further inquiries about applying to OAR or about specific positions, feel free to contact V.P. Literary Rachel Fernandes at literary@uesa.ca

Applications can be submitted online via email, or in person in the UESA office (Arts 321, they're posted on the door). Application deadline is Wednesday, May 7th.

If you would like to apply online, please send an email to literary@uesa.ca to get a copy of the application form.

-----------------

The Ottawa Arts Review is the official English-language literary and visual arts journal of the University of Ottawa. It is a not-for-profit publication, established, managed and produced by student volunteers who wish to promote and encourage the appreciation of both literary and visual art in Ottawa. The Ottawa Arts Review gives an equal voice to local, Canadian, and international artists, cultivating a vibrant and positive setting that facilitates creative exchange between emerging and established artists alike.

Ottawa Arts Review features original works of literary prose, poetry, drama, visual art, and photography, as well as reviews and interviews that relate to literary and visual arts.
307360422746968.name: Now Hiring: Ottawa Arts Review 2014-2015 Staff!

310262919122088.description:
Roller Derby Saved My Soul is back in Ottawa for one night only at the Arts Court Theatre on May 30th at 7:30 PM before setting out across the country to 8 Canadian Fringe Festivals. This performance is a fundraiser for the tour and a feature-length documentary based on the tour called On the Fringe.
Members from Ottawa's own Roller Derby leagues will be in attendance to give everyone a demonstration of the sport and maybe even recruit some FRESH MEAT. A reception will be held afterwards with snacks, booze and fun activities (PLUS, you can buy drinks before the show and bring them into the theatre). Come celebrate with Nancy and her team before she rolls off across the country!

Tickets:
General Admission $25
Student/artist/unwaged $15
Click here to purchase http://www.eventbrite.com/e/fundraiser-roller-derby-saved-my-soul-in-ottawa-for-one-night-only-tickets-11077050757

Roller Derby Saved My Soul - www.rollerderbysavedmysoul.com
Writer/performer: Nancy Kenny
Director: Tania Levy
Sound design: Steven Lafond 
Choreography: Patricia Allison
About the play:
Amy is a shy comic book geek who envies her younger sister’s exciting life. June is strong, brash and plays extreme sports. Through June, Amy discovers roller derby, gains confidence and finally grows into person she's always wanted to be.
Comics, fandom and the struggles of the introvert: In a world of tropes, one woman gets off the couch and unleashes the hero within in this critically acclaimed action-adventure comedy on roller skates.
Awards and recognition:
Critic's Pick - Atlantic Fringe Festival
Winner - Outstanding Fringe Production - Ottawa
Winner - Best in Fest - Ottawa Fringe Festival
Winner - Best in Venue - Hamilton Fringe Festival
4 STARS - Global TV
4 STARS - Vue Weekly
"Roller Derby Saved My Soul skates straight into your heart." – Edmonton Journal
"Kenny is a charmer... undeniably original."– Montreal Gazette

“Perfect escapism and purely satisfying entertainment... Go see it.” – CBC Ottawa

“(Kenny) celebrates the hero in all of us, and makes us want to go out, lace up a pair of skates, and like this play, kick some ass.” – Fully Fringed

“…tons of laughs mixed with genuine warmth, and a transformation-to-derby sequence that must be seen to be believed… Nancy K is one of the premiere comedic actresses in town… and it sure as shit won’t be a secret much longer.” – The Visitorium

“Roller Derby Saved My Soul is the kind of light-hearted, honestly funny story you want to find at Fringe – and Kenny has it for you, geared up in elbow pads and a mouth guard.” – The Wig

"This is a must see.” – The Hamilton View
